Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
The assignment of the PI to the role of Chief Scientist at the Central Transantarctic Mountains field camp by the Office of Polar Programs has presented the PI with the opportunity to re-examine a unique geological locality at the head of Nimrod Glacier. During the 1985-86 field season, a diamictite interpreted to be of glacial origin was discovered by the PI on the Cotton Plateau. Relative dates indicated that the diamictite is of Neoproterozoic age. It is believed that this is the first evidence of Neoproterozoic glaciation in Antarctica. During the 1985-86 field season, the PI also discovered a volcanic rhyolite at Cotton Plateau interbedded with the sedimentary sequence containing the diamictite. In this proposal, the PI proposes to sample the rhyolite for U-Pb analyses on zircons to provide an age for the diamictite and allow for correlation of this deposit with the global Neoproterozoic glacial subdivisions. Detailed examination of rocks in the vicinity of the diamictite will also be undertaken to identify additional localities with a glacial affinity, thus our understanding of Antarctica?s role during this important interval of Earth history.

Broader impacts:
A student currently working on a M.S. thesis on rocks collected in the Transantarctic Mountains will be involved in the fieldwork and follow up lab work. The proposed field work will give a broader context for the thesis work. Because the field work will be conducted from the CTAM camp, the student will have the opportunity to interact with a broad range of other geologists. Scientifically, the Neoproterozoic glaciation is currently a research theme of great international interest and the ability to demonstrate and accurately date Neoproterozoic glaciation in Antarctica will have significant scientific impact.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report – NSF OPP 1059489

 

Sometimes scientific results are not what a scientist predicts.  This is true of my recent research project in the Transantarctic Mountains. The research goals of the project were to collect and date a rhyolite (a fine-grained igneous rock) at Cotton Plateau in the central Transantarctic Mountains. The rhyolite, discovered and first mapped in 1986, had been interpreted based on field relations to have been erupted volcanically in a sequence of Neoproterozoic (650-750 million-year) glacial deposits. Because glacial deposits have been dated from three separate episodes during the Neoproterozoic in Australia (adjacent to Antarctica before continental drift) we had hoped to be able to pinpoint the period during which the Antarctic examples were deposited, and thereby make a correlation with the Australian counterparts.

 

The rhyolite was successfully collected and subsequently dated at a laboratory at MIT specializing in the U-Pb dating technique.  The results showed that the age of the rhyolite is 536 million years old. Since this age is younger than a sequence of sedimentary rock that overlies (is younger than) the glacial deposits, we are left with the conclusion that the original interpretation of the rhyolite being volcanic and erupted at the same time as the glacial sequence was in error, and that the rhyolite must have been an intrusive rock intruded into the glacial sequence at ~536 Ma.
